—I am surprised that this question should be asked of me by the opposition, in view of the answer Senator Ray gave to a question earlier today from Senator Alston, and in view of the answer I have just given about the concern of the Australian business community and Australian employers about this legislation. The other concern—indeed, the deeper concern—about this legislation is that it is a blueprint for what the coalition, in the form of Mr Howard and Mr Reith, would do were they ever to be in government.

PARA.TAB: The concern that is often expressed to me by the Australian business community is that we have come into a period of high industrial harmony in Australia. We have in the workplace, through the accord and through the cooperative arrangements that have been put in place, employers and employees working together to grow the size of the national economy and share the proceeds between them in a way which, through the efforts of both partners, is fully respected. That is a golden achievement by this government.

The figures that I gave you of 76 working days per thousand lost last year, compared with 797 working days lost through industrial disputation in 1981—in your period of government—are a key reason why employers in this country value industrial harmony, hate industrial confrontation and disdain the divisive nature of legislation of this sort.

One needs to look at some of the detail of this legislation to understand why people are upset and annoyed by it to the point where they have chosen to take the action in Western Australia that they have. Let me select one part of this legislation which as well as any other part explains what the concern is. In Western Australia, under state awards, back when real records were kept and before the industrial inspectorate was run down and understaffed so that true work by it could never be carried out, there were annually between $4 million to $6 million of underpayments of workers in positions in which they had no protection recovered through the industrial court. If you cannot get the evidence because you are obstructed from entering the workplace, you cannot protect the rights of those workers. That is why those workers are concerned.

What is the concern of employers here? If you are in competition with an employer who undercuts his wages and therefore undercuts you in terms of the price of your product because he has broken the award and is unscrupulous, and you are paying the award, the right wages and charging out at that level, you have a government encouragement to unscrupulous employers to destroy the community standing of scrupulous and moral employers and undercut the price of them by dudding their workers on salary. That is one of the key reasons why people on both the employer side of the fence and on the workers side of the fence as well as independent commentators are opposed to this legislation. —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to the recent comments the government has made on the issue of how citizenship laws impact on the assessment of claims for refugee status in Australia. Can the minister inform the Senate of the legal advice his department has received on the issue of Portuguese nationality and asylum seekers from East Timor?

—I thank Senator Jacinta Collins for raising this question. She is right: we have had advice prepared for us, and it should be placed in context. That advice was prepared because the refugee determination process has been considering this issue and that process has asked government to submit advice to it.

PARA.TAB: In terms of how the request for advice arose, the Refugee Review Tribunal has been set up under legislation passed by this parliament to be an independent review body for those who seek to challenge refusals of refugee status. It assesses cases before it on a case by case basis and makes up its mind on the basis of the law, the facts and Australia's obligations under the refugees convention.

The tribunal, it must be made clear, does not act at the direction of government. It does, however, seek submissions from my department from time to time to assist it with decision making. As senators will know, the government may appeal decisions of the tribunal and sometimes does so to the Federal Court where particularly important aspects of law are at issue.

In terms of this process, in February this year, in the context of a case concerning an East Timorese asylum seeker, the tribunal wrote to the secretary to my department asking for submissions from the department on the Portuguese nationality issue. In June it wrote again asking for submissions or information on the issue of the nationality of East Timorese. It raised related citizenship and other nationality issues again in June, July and September this year.

The issue of citizenship was raised. The question of citizenship is one that is determined by the domestic law of particular countries. My department, in an attempt to settle the citizenship issue once and for all, responded to the request from the tribunal by seeking information from an expert on Portuguese citizenship law, Professor Ramos of the University of Coimbra in Portugal. When that advice was received, the department sought further legal advice from the AG's department about Australia's obligations under the refugees convention. Once that advice was received, it was submitted to the tribunal, as requested, so the tribunal could inform itself of the issue. I table both the AG's advice and Professor Ramos's advice.

As senators will see, as I have previously said, the advice indicates that, if East Timorese asylum seekers have available to them Portuguese citizenship, Australia does not have protection obligations towards them under the refugees convention unless they exhaust other citizenship rights. This particular aspect arises from the UN definition of refugee, which provides that people have to exhaust all available citizenship rights before obtaining asylum status in a particular country. The advice also makes clear that those who have citizenship available to them are not able to enliven our protection obligations by merely refusing to take up that citizenship.

So what is the status of the legal advice? It forms the basis of a submission from the department which is forwarded to the Refugee Review Tribunal for consideration by decision makers. Of course, the tribunal and decision makers will each be able to take this into account as well as other relevant factors that are before them in each particular case and make a decision based on the case before them and based also on the international definition of `refugee'.

PARA.TAB: The second part of Senator Reynolds' question was: will we introduce such a tax? We won't. We won't because goods and services taxes put up prices and hence push along inflation. Goods and services taxes are flat taxes. The rich pay the same for the product as do the poor. Everyone pays the same, irrespective of wealth. It is a regressive tax. It also means an increase in the general level of taxation.

The compensatory adjustment mechanisms have all been condemned by the welfare lobby—by the churches and welfare groups. It is administratively complex. What we have seen, coming off a very high peak of high demand and high growth last year, is the economy coming into a more sustainable level of growth this year. As a consequence, if you are comparing figures for this year with the figures last year, those figures will show a decline.

We are now on a more straight line with continuing and sustainable economic growth. That is the good news for this industry and that is the good news for the rest of Australian industry. They do not want booms and busts; they want sustainable economic growth. That is what we have now delivered. It is true that wholesale sales taxes have been introduced and, to some extent, that may have helped to ameliorate the demand. But I return to the fundamental point: that the economy is on a sustainable growth course and that demand is likely to be more consistent; that provides better forward planning and more predictable consumption levels for automotive makers and other producers in Australia. That for them, in the longer haul, is better news.

In addition to direct financial considerations, there are a range of objectives which the government is required to meet with any major asset sale. PARA.TAB: I think it is very interesting that you, Senator Alston, come in here with your colleagues and ask questions and condemn industrial action that is taken on the basis of workers trying to protect certain rights. That really begins to highlight, and now illuminates, your position on industrial relations. It is bringing out the truth about where you really stand and what the coalition's policy will be at the next election, or after the next election, with regard to industrial relations.

Right now all we know is what your policy was at the last election. You keep trying to shift around in the sand and keep your head down and not do anything or say anything, but we know that primarily your position is that there will be a single minimum hourly rate. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has said on behalf of the coalition that the Western Australian industrial relations package is the coalition's model and that that is what they will have.

Essentially what that will bring to the working people of Australia is a single minimum hourly wage. It is worth noting that the Victorian government—and Mr Howard also supports their industrial relations program—sought to apply to the Industrial Relations Commission of Victoria to have a minimum hourly rate of $8.30. It is not quite the $3 which the opposition said it was going to have as the youth wage last time. They are now saying, `We are not going to have a $3 per hour wage this time.' They do not know whether it is going to be $3 or $3.50 or $4.

They will reduce all of the award conditions down to four weeks annual leave, 12 months unpaid parental leave and 10 days non-cumulative sick leave. They are the four basic minimum standards that you are prepared to give people. Other things such as overtime, penalty rates, annual leave loading, a 38-hour week, public holidays, unfair dismissal protection and superannuation are all up for negotiation. None of the things along those lines will be protected.

I think it is worth noting how well the industrial relations program, which is proposed by the opposition, has worked in Victoria. If we look at what has happened in Victoria we find that workers have, since the introduction of this program in November 1992, lost an average of $430 per year before tax, have no guarantee of a 38- or 40-hour week, have had their sick leave entitlements reduced, have no entitlement to pro rata sick leave and have no entitlement to redundancy pay.

This is really all about your being honest enough to come and tell the Australian people exactly what you are going to propose in terms of industrial relations and employment measures. You need to tell them what you will do, what you will offer them and what you will give them at the next election. You should do it prior to the election and not do what other conservative state governments have done—promise the world, get into government and then slaughter the workers of the respective states, particularly Western Australia and Victoria.

Hundreds of thousands of workers have sought to transfer to federal awards simply because of the very nature of the industrial relations program that Jeff Kennett has. We have likewise seen the same thing in Western Australia. What we have also seen is the Western Australian government trying to stop this. If workers and their unions seek to transfer to federal awards, you will abolish the state award under which they were previously employed. That is not on and should not be supported.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Minchin this day, relating to the car industry and taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked about the car industry in August and referred to the drop in sales in July. The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) said at that time, `Sales always drop in July. You have to expect this sort of thing to happen.' Now we have the sales figures for September and they show that car sales dropped by 12 1/2 per cent compared with August and that they are down 3.9 per cent on the September 1994 figures. So even in seasonally adjusted terms clearly the car industry is suffering considerably from the increase in the wholesale sales tax on cars.

PARA.TAB: That is exactly what the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industry said in a statement on 6 October. It said that sales in new motor vehicles fell sharply in September as the full impact of the wholesale sales tax increases in the May federal budget were felt. They went on to say that the decrease is a further reflection of the industry's plight with respect to the after effects of the sales tax increases. They have nailed the real cause for this dramatic slump in car sales in Australia. They go on to point out, despite what the minister has given us by way of answer, that there has been absolutely no growth in the Australian car industry in the past decade.

So, after 12 years of this Labor government, the car industry is stuck in a groove. The sales for 1995 are expected to be no more than sales of cars in 1985. We have had a significant increase in population, yet there has been no growth in this industry, partly, as the chamber itself says, because of the sales tax increases which this government has put on to it. What has actually happened is that in the 1995 budget the tax was increased by virtually one-third, from 16 per cent to 21 per cent, and then another one per cent on 1 July, taking the total tax to 22 per cent on motor vehicles. That is a one-third increase in the tax that ordinary Australians have to pay to purchase a new motor vehicle.

The worst part of this is the appalling broken promise that this represents. On 26 February 1992 the Prime Minister said, `From tomorrow, the sales tax on new cars currently subjected to the 20 per cent rate will be permanently lowered to 15 per cent.' He went on to proclaim the virtues of that reduction in tax. He said it was a permanent reduction. Once the 1993 election was out of the way—a couple of years have passed, of course—`Well, that was a countercyclical measure and now it's time to increase the tax.' It is a most outrageous broken promise. It was one of the most deceitful things that were said before the 1992 campaign. It was done by the government in a panic, simply to match the tax of 15 per cent that we were proposing to put on motor vehicles. Of course, the effect of this outrageous broken promise is to put a $1,200 increase on the price of a new Falcon or Holden. This is the government that professes to look after the battlers. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so such of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette from moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely, a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1839, standing in the name of Senator Chamarette for this day, relating to consideration of the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: I am seeking to suspend standing orders today because on the Notice Paper is a bill which has enormous ramifications for Australia's human rights and environment record and our standing in the world community.

PARA.TAB: The motion which I wish to put to the Senate would remove the Administrative Decisions (Effects of International Instruments) Bill 1995 from the Notice Paper and be redrafted. There are several reasons why this is vitally important.

It is an extremely serious matter to suggest that a bill be withdrawn from the Notice Paper. We have not considered this lightly. However, this bill, which was listed in the motion that I gave notice of yesterday as No. 14 on the Notice Paper, is bad law making. We will not be a party to this chamber compromising its integrity and processes without some protest. The bill has made a mockery of our Senate committee system, it does not have the substantial backing of any part of the Australian community and its continuing existence, let alone enactment, is damaging Australia's international reputation.

The outcome of the Senate legal and constitutional committee's inquiry into this bill calls into question the Senate committee process. The vast majority of written and oral submissions, bar that of the Attorney-General's Department, opposed the bill and opposed it in strident terms.
Elizabeth Evatt, in her oral submission to the committee, made this comment about the bill:

SPEECH.PARA: It gives the message that we have no reasonable expectation that our government will comply with obligations that it has undertaken. I would be ashamed to have to say that at an international forum.

Joseph O'Reilly of the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties said, `the Teoh bill is something which is regrettable and fundamentally flawed'. Robert Ludbrook of the National Children's and Youth Law Centre said the bill was `misconceived' and should be withdrawn. Chris Sidotti, the Human Rights Commissioner, said the bill was `unnecessary', `undesirable' and introduced `logical inconsistencies into federal law'. He went on to say, `It is a retreat from Australia's good record in supporting international human rights treaties.' I could go on but I have only the briefest of time to outline the urgency of this motion I am seeking to put to the chamber.

PARA.TAB: To be fair, the committee report adequately sets out the opposition to the bill. This, however, makes it even more surprising that the majority committee recommendations ignore the input of highly respected representatives of the Australian community. The only people arguing for this bill are politicians. A committee process which so blatantly ignores community input lacks any credibility.

The failure of the parliament to be a conduit for community views has meant that a coalition of community, religious and industry groups have come together to oppose the bill. Later this week these groups will unveil a campaign against this retrograde legislation. This chamber should not be party to a debate on a bill which so blatantly fails to represent the wishes of the people. The bill is shoddy law making. We need to engage in a meaningful consultation process which leads to a comprehensive approach to Australia's international obligations—not a piecemeal one.

While this bill remains on the Notice Paper our international standing will deteriorate. If the bill passes, this deterioration will accelerate, ultimately threatening to destroy any positive work the government has done in international human rights and environmental arenas. To think that Australia will somehow escape international condemnation for this legislation suggests that it is the government which is in collusion with the fairies at the bottom of the garden, not the minor parties.

The motives of the government on this issue must be questioned. The government says this bill will eliminate administrative uncertainty. The one thing the committee processes did do was to soundly debunk this myth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: Senator Chamarette earlier went to arguments about the thing rather than to the urgency. But at that stage, because her arguments were directed at specific points which may, at least deferentially, come back to urgency, I didn't object. We are now in a five minute debate as a result of having changed standing orders et cetera. But Senator Chamarette is now really starting to get into the substance of the matter which will be the subject of the following debate if her motion is carried.
—This is a matter of establishing urgency, Senator Chamarette.

—I understand that and I am establishing its urgency. I believe that the importance of the bill is justification for the motion to remove it from the Notice Paper. It is very difficult to argue the urgency of its removal without looking at the content of the bill. The content of the bill is the central argument for its removal. I urge my colleagues to allow this motion to be passed to enable us to have a longer debate. I certainly have not exhausted the substantive issues. I urge my colleagues to support the urgency of the motion. (Time expired)

—The coalition will not be supporting the suspension motion moved by Senator Chamarette. The prime reason for the opposition's view is that this bill will again come before this chamber and Senator Chamarette will have her chance at that time to make her points. I quite understand a number of the issues raised by Senator Chamarette, but not one of those issues indicates to me why this motion should be dealt with now. In debating with Senator Chamarette we could say that we have as strong an interest in the treaty making foreign affairs power as Senator Chamarette and the government may have.

PARA.TAB: We have clearly defined policy differences with the government on a whole range of issues in this area. We have been saying for quite some time that the government has gone about the treaty making process in a haphazard and cavalier way and that it has not realised the consequences of its actions. This bill that Senator Chamarette is now saying is so urgent is in response to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) finding out that some of the things he was telling the community about the impact of signing treaties and being a party to conventions were simply incorrect. The Attorney-General has now introduced a bill to remedy the situation.

Senator Chamarette does not want that bill to be dealt with. Why should her views on that bill take precedence over our views on a whole range of bills that are here to be dealt with? There are a number of family law bills in my portfolio that I would like to see dealt with. There is the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1994 (1995), which has strangely fallen to the bottom of the Notice Paper. That bill would allow corruption to be listed as a class 2 offence. I could argue here that that bill is more important than any other bill on the Notice Paper at the moment because it will allow the Wood royal commission to gain access to a far wider range of telephone intercept information than it is now able to get.

Corruption is not listed as an offence in relation to the telecommunications interception bill. That means that some of the information that the commission can get is not so much second-hand as second-order information. It is information that law enforcement agencies come across because they have an intercept on a drug runner, a murderer, or whatever. They cannot undertake an intercept first off because of corruption. If they could, there would be a lot more information available to the Wood royal commission in New South Wales.

It begs the question why this government introduced the bill. The government had a clear indication from us that we would support the bill. However, the bill has been moved to the bottom of the Notice Paper. I understand the sense of urgency that Senator Chamarette tries to bring to this matter, but the debate on the treaty making process is not going to go away. Undoubtedly it will be an issue at the election. I do not see why it should be dealt with today over and above other items such as the telecommunications interception bill where time is running out. There is a clock on the Wood royal commission in New South Wales and it could be that if that bill is not passed there will be information on corruption in the Australian Federal Police and the New South Wales police force that does not come to light and is not brought before the commission. The reason for that is that the government has put the bill far lower down the Notice Paper than I believe it should be placed.

I could come in here tomorrow and move a motion and take up half an hour of the Senate's time making the case that I believe that that bill should be higher up the order. But if each shadow minister and the Democrats—as they rotate their membership around the phone box, putting on one shadow minister's hat one day and another shadow minister's hat the next—came in and moved a motion to change the order on the Notice Paper to put on a bill that they think is most urgent, we would never deal with any of the bills that we all agree are urgent.

Senator Chamarette just has to accept that the bill provides a mechanism for debate on this bill. It will be debated. It is not as if lives are going to be lost. It is not as if information on corrupt police officers is going to be lost. Information on corruption will be lost if the telecommunications interception bill is not passed. Senator Chamarette will get her chance to have this debate at a proper time. Bad luck that you do not win government in the lower house. I hope that when we win government in the lower house we will be able to control the agenda. The stunning reality that has to dawn on Senator Chamarette is that those people over there sadly won a majority in the lower house and formed a government and they have the opportunity to control the agenda. Those opposite control the agenda and we do not agree with their priority in respect of this bill. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly hope that this bill will be deferred. One of the reasons for discussing it today is to get the opposition to once again consider its stance as to whether it really should support the bill. The opposition seems to have been giving the message to all and sundry that it will support this bill—one of the most appalling pieces of legislation to come before the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs conducted an investigation into this bill and had a public hearing. It might be useful for the opposition and all senators to consider the people who were present at the public hearing: Justice Elizabeth Evatt; the Law Reform Commission; the Chamber of Industry and Commerce—hardly a radical body; the Human Rights Commission; the Law Council of Australia; the Women's Justice Commission; the Council for Overseas Aid; Greenpeace; the Children's and Youth Law Centre; and several others.

It was a sight to behold. All those people were present at the table along with representatives from the federal Attorney-General's Department. The only voices in support of the bill—and I suspect under instruction from the government—were those of the representatives of the Attorney-General's Department. There was not a single voice amongst all the witnesses before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which expressed a view that this bill should be supported.

The concerns they expressed were twofold. Firstly, Australia is obviously going to be held in very low esteem indeed by the global community when we say, `Yes, we will sign this treaty. We will even ratify it. But no, we don't want our decision makers, our public officials, to take any notice of it. We want them to ignore it.' Over the years we have had a process where human rights standards as reflected in international treaties and in international law have gradually been adopted by the legal systems of the various countries, including Australia. In Australia, international law as a persuasive authority has certainly been taken account of in judicial decisions and in the further development of our common law.

With this action the government simply wants to put a stop to that process and deliver us to a position in the world community where people will point their fingers at us and say, `They say one thing in this treaty but they don't intend to abide by it because they are saying to their public officials, "Ignore it. Don't pay any attention to it because you don't have to."' It might be useful to discuss the Teoh decision because the view might be put about that the treaty obligation has not entered into domestic law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. In the first part of his speech, Senator Spindler went to why he thought this should be urgently dealt with today. He also said that it is a stunt to convince the opposition, and he is now going to the material facts of the bill and the arguments on the bill. Even though we give greater scope in these five-minute contributions to do that, he really is not entitled to go to the substance. He has to go to the urgency, why this is urgent. He can refer to the subject matter in passing, but not make a whole speech on that.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I uphold the point of order. I ask Senator Spindler to relate his comments to the urgency of the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was necessary to advert to some extent to the content of the bill to press the urgency as to why both the government and the opposition need to reconsider their positions, and to let the world know that Australia, after all, means something when it signs and ratifies a treaty.

—The only argument evinced here for suspending standing orders to delete a bill from the agenda is the view that it will do us international damage, and there has been no evidence at all produced today to justify that. The only evidence brought was that certain Australian citizens do not like it. When we get to the question of urgency, there is also some urgency that this government may occasionally be given the honour of debating in this place some of its own legislation.

PARA.TAB: I draw to the Senate's attention where we will be heading today. We started off with an hour of question time, which is essentially opposition business, followed by half an hour of noting of questions and 10 minutes of notices of motions, again basically for non-government senators. We actually allowed Senator Alston to have his motion made formal so we did not have to waste another half an hour. We are now spending half an hour or more on this if it is carried. Then we have an urgency motion for half an hour before we go on to deal with Auditor-General's reports and reports from committees. Then we will have motions on committee membership, and a resolution from Senator Hill on Senate committee business. Then, if we are lucky and no other little things pop in, we might get on to some legislation.

I might point out to this Senate that, in terms of urgency, there are 31 bills listed here for debate. At the end of every session I listen to all the preachy speeches here about how the government has not got its legislative program ready.

TALK.START.PARA: —Make it 30 and it will be easier to get through.

—I acknowledge that. I am actually now talking about Senator Vanstone's point. We get all these preachy statements about the government not organising its programs, that it did not bring the legislation in early enough. There are 31 bills if you want to get to work, so don't, for heaven's sake, come in here in six or eight weeks time, or whenever it is, and say that we did not have our program ready. They are there listed on the red, and we are ready to debate them. We also believe that the bill to which the Western Australian Greens object should be dealt with in the normal manner, debated in this chamber and carried on the numbers or defeated on the numbers.

—If I could take a point of order, Senator Ray is not speaking to the urgency or not of this motion. He has strayed from the point, and I would like him to be brought to order. Whenever Senator Spindler or myself were making points that strayed from it, Senator Ray was very quick to take it up.

—On the point of order, I am talking about the urgency of the program and the urgency of this today. In fact, I am right on the point of urgency. I have not gone into the substance matter of the legislation, nor do I intend to.
—That's why it's urgent.
—That is what you say, that that is why it is urgent. That is for this Senate to decide when it debates the bill. When the bill comes up, that is when you make your points.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I have just made the point that, in terms of urgency, there are other competing priorities here. One of the other competing priorities is the 31 bills, one of which you object to, that are on this particular list. As far as the government is concerned, we should get on with the Senate business and deal with some of these things. Today, of course, we had Senator Spindler let the cat out of the bag when he said that this is a stunt to get some of the substantive matters debated here in the hope they will influence some of the senators here. Apart from being a very naive view, I have never seen that happen. It is merely a stunt.
—There is always a first time; one lives in hope.

—That is right. I am glad you have again confirmed that it is merely a stunt to get some substantive debate on the record. This is a device you are using; therefore, it is not urgent. What is urgent is your opportunism. That is what is urgent about this particular urgency motion—your opportunism, your sneakiness in thinking we will get the substantive matters on the record here because we each get a five-minute speech.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that you have not proved any urgency on this issue. The one point that you may have been able to hang your case around was that this is doing us enormous damage out there in the international community. You did not bring in any evidence on that; you did not quote any figures on that. You kept going back to the substance of the act and drifting away. You drifted to the substance of the act because the real motive for bringing this on was to have a little five-minute preachy speech in previewing the legislation. You know that you will not get it up; nevertheless, you put it up for those reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a point of order.
—Thanks for the point of order, because I have run out of material.
—My point of order is that it is not for the minister to impute motives to Senator Chamarette.

—On the point of order: when someone does something in this chamber to interrupt the normal flow, I am entitled to ask why they are doing so. Are they doing it as a stunt, or are they doing it because they have a genuine concern? I acknowledge that there is genuine concern, but I also acknowledge that this has a great element of stunt about it.
—I do not think there was an imputation there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The starting point is to ask why standing orders need to be suspended on an urgent basis to canvass the motion that Senator Chamarette puts to the Senate. That motion, in paragraph (a), basically criticises the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill as put by the government and, in paragraph (b), resolves that the bill should be discharged from the Notice Paper and redrafted. The question, of course, is: where is the urgency in that? Why should that be dealt with today and not canvassed when the bill comes before the Senate within the next fortnight, or perhaps within the fortnight's sitting after that?

PARA.TAB: I appreciate that in relation to this bill Senator Chamarette and Senator Spindler take a different point of view from the opposition and the government. However, the question is simply one of urgency. Why should we deal with the bill today rather than when it comes before the Senate? I fail to see where the urgency is in having this matter debated today and having the bill struck from the Notice Paper. What prejudice would the Australian people suffer by not having this matter debated today? That really is the question that should be asked.

Over the next two or three weeks I doubt that any decision will be made by a Commonwealth decision maker, or any treaty or convention entered into by Australia, that would have ramifications which would be prejudicial to the Australian people. I fail to see where Australia would suffer internationally by not having this matter debated today rather than when the bill comes on. As the minister has stated, when the bill comes on, the matter can be debated more fully and the matter of substance can be discussed.
I think the bill seeks to state what people have understood the law to be hitherto. In the preamble of the bill it states:
However, international instruments by which Australia is bound or to which Australia is a party—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: I believe Senator Ellison is now going to the substance of the issue rather than the urgency of the issue.

—On the point of order: what Senator Ellison was doing was pointing out the differential in that this is probably not new law but a reinforcement of old law. That does go to the question of urgency and is directly related to it.
—That was precisely the point that I was going to make.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I believe that you are in order, Senator Ellison.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I was saying was that the bill in its preamble states:

PARA.TAB: However, international instruments by which Australia is bound or to which Australia is a party do not form a part of Australian law unless Australian legislation provides otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: I put to the Senate that that was the understanding of the government, of the wider community and, I stress, of the judicial system in this country until the case of Teoh. This bill simply seeks to reinforce what was understood until the Teoh decision. There is nothing new or drastic being brought in by this bill; nothing which is cataclysmic by nature. It simply restates what people understood the law to be. Therefore, this question of urgency does not really arise.

PARA.TAB: I fail to see why standing orders should be suspended to debate the question of striking this from the Notice Paper. For those reasons, there is no prejudice which can be established which would be suffered if this issue were not debated today. There is nothing innovative in the bill. There is nothing that it would do to change things drastically so that people would be prejudicially affected. For those reasons, the case for urgency is not made out. I think the substance of the bill itself can be debated fully when the bill comes before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of reasons why Senator Chamarette's motion to suspend standing orders is urgent today. One that springs to mind became very obvious yesterday when I was involved in a public hearing of the radioactive waste inquiry. We heard evidence from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in relation to the varied treaties that relate specifically to radioactive waste—and it looked at around a dozen of them—and I asked the department how many treaties had actually been looked at from the department's point of view in relation to the anti-Teoh legislation. Would it surprise anyone to know the answer? Zero.

PARA.TAB: We had from the opposition a panic station in relation to the desertification treaty. They wanted to know every last nth of implication with Australia's signing of the desertification treaty, yet the urgency—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Desertification and other things are of great interest, but it escapes me how that relates to the important issue of urgency.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I was waiting for the point about urgency, but I think Senator Margetts was about to introduce it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The implications here are that only one department—that is, the Attorney-General's Department—has actually looked at the implications of the bill. The urgency is that Australia has signed thousands of treaties, and either all or part of any treaty may no longer have legal standing in the courts of Australia. That means that the individual will not have the ability to utilise those thousands of treaties, including the International Labor Organisation—anything warm and fuzzy that Australia has ever signed.

PARA.TAB: That is the urgency here. It is urgent because it has been slipped unobtrusively onto the agenda. It is rapidly reaching a conclusion without the general community having any idea of its ramifications. It is urgent because the Lib-Lab coalition here has decided that it will disregard the vast majority of extremely well-informed community organisations and individuals who have made submissions.

Raising it as a matter of urgency is not a stunt—as Senator Ray has accused Senator Spindler and, by inference, Senator Chamarette. It is a legitimate approach and is necessary to draw the attention of the community to something that the government and opposition are about to perpetrate by their numbers. I do not believe that the majority of people on this side of the house even know the implications, and I believe it has not even been discussed in caucus.

The urgency is that the ramifications are such that it is so dangerous in relation to the treaties that have been signed and will no longer have standing in a court. Let us think, for instance, about the Ramsar treaties, the wetlands treaties—all of those for which the only last resort for people is the implication that the court may be able to take those into consideration if any court decision were made. That is not there, and you have wiped it out.

If the urgency were there electorally, it is because we will be telling the voters loud and clear what you have done by taking this decision unthinkingly and not even allowing your own departments to look at the ramifications of what you are doing in this bill. It is urgent because the community deserves the right to know what the government and the coalition are doing between them.

We know the opposition does not want the federal government to make the treaty powers. We know that. We did not actually know that about the government until today. It will mean that both of the major parties in the future may go more easily into treaties. But they may not be worth the paper they are written on, because anybody who does not want human rights, who does not like obligations on the environment, who does not want to see the world working together on the things we must do, will be able to block that by simply using state governments to block international progress on things we must do in order to survive as a planet. Therefore, it is a day that must be noted as urgent, and it is a day which we believe this side of the chamber will live to regret. We know the opposition's views on treaties already. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The failure of the Prime Minister to condemn the political and economic blockade of Western Australia by supporting the Trades & Labour Council ahead of the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: In rising to address this issue I would like to place it clearly on the public record that there is a necessity for this motion before the chamber today because the Labor government led by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and others have decided on a political response to a situation in another state which they do not agree with. I want to parallel that with what occurred following the last election when we had a similar situation. We had what was known at that time as the Victorian IR legislation and Western Australian legislation—which is now for some reason being called the first wave of the legislation. We also had the government's Industrial Relations Reform Act.

PARA.TAB: At that time, the government's response to a situation we did not agree with was a legislative response in the form of overriding state legislation by using ILO conventions, external affairs powers and a number of other legislative responses. That is the correct response if they disagree with a particular situation at a particular time. But for us to have a situation where the federal government—led by the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley), the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), and Senator Ray and Senator Cook here in the chamber today—in refusing to condemn a political and economic blockade of a state, in this case, my state of Western Australia, is one of the lowest points that the political situation has reached in this country.

As time goes by they will very much regret the decision they have taken because it is the worst form of the rule of anarchy that one could possibly think of. It will also test the mettle of some of the Western Australians on the other side of the chamber—and everyone in this chamber. Would they prefer that type of response to something that they disagree with or the position they took following the last election? I say, `Shame on them.'

The real problem is that Mr Keating, as we know, is in trouble in terms of his current political position. He has chosen to use this type of route to try to get out of it. It is not really the Western Australians who are orchestrating this; when you dig into the depths, you find it is the Transport Workers Union, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Keating and Mr Kelty who are the architects.

Had there been the provisions which are being put into the Western Australian legislation of secret ballots there would be no strike or boycott today. In fact, it would have been absolutely and totally defeated in Western Australia by enormous numbers of trade union members because they do not want it. In fact, they reject this action.

If it had not been for the TWU putting some picket lines up today, the boycott would have failed. They had to physically move in to stop a number of people taking up their normal work positions and carrying out their normal services to the Western Australian community. The Prime Minister is not accepting his national responsibility in terms of what is good for the nation; he is putting in place his own political agenda and taking sides in this case with a small section of the trade union movement. If he had not done this in the way he has done, we would not be debating this motion today.

I am quite certain, as I said earlier, that as time goes by we will find that government ministers will regret the position they have taken in this matter. It is a very tragic day. I want to quote one of the press comments today. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: A blockade of any state is an act of economic vandalism, but a blockade of Australia's top performing exporting state is simply economic suicide.

That quote really highlights the depths to which this government will go at this time in their scaremongering campaign for the next election. It will do no good for them or the economy of Australia. Even more, it will do no good for the people of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: It poses this question: why would Prime Minister Keating take this stance when we are dealing with the best performing economic state in this country? Last year, the state had a $11 billion surplus on its current account, that is its exports over imports. Contrast that with the total $26 billion deficit that we have at the federal level. Look at unemployment. In Western Australia, youth unemployment is 10 percentage points below the national average.

TALK.START.PARA: —So why change the system?

—I will come to that. Reform has to go on. You have misrepresented that reform. Unemployment in this state is one per cent below the national average. By far and away it has been the best performing state economically over the last two or three years.

PARA.TAB: Why change the system? Why would people be frightened of things such as a secret ballot? You change the system so that events like those of today cannot occur unless the majority of people involved want them to occur. Why should anybody walk away from or be frightened of a secret ballot? Why should anybody be concerned about people having the opportunity to determine where their political donations go? There is nothing wrong with that. These types of things have been described as draconian. That is not draconian.

What is draconian is the failure of previous Labor governments in Western Australia, in not having repealed the Masters and Servants Act 1892, the Truck Act 1899 or the Trade Union Act 1902. One could go on with what is being repealed and replaced in this legislation. The bottom line is that the changes are very minor. But that is not even the point. I respect the right of those opposite to disagree with points of that legislation, but I do not respect their right to support an economic boycott in a state for political purposes, particularly when that state is the one I come from. That is what is wrong with the actions of the government.

In the last 24 or 36 hours, Mr Keating and Mr Beazley have tried to wriggle out of their earlier position by saying that they neither support nor condone it. That is very different from the positions they are reported to have put last week, even if they were partially misrepresented then. I do not believe they were, because I have talked to some of the people who were at the functions and meetings where these things were said. Mr Keating and Mr Beazley have put one foot on each side of a barbed wire fence. At least Mr Brereton said that he supported the position in Western Australia; he made it quite clear. But he is absolutely and totally wrong in the position he took.

Because of the position they hold, they are now not prepared to say that this is not the way business should be done in Australia. We should not have to put up with the damage that is being done to the economy in Western Australia and which will flow into the Australian economy. We should not have to put up with the damage that is being done to our overall international representation. These reforms in Western Australia are being carried through. If a response was required from the federal government, it should have been a legislative response. This government should not be supporting a blockade of the state of Western Australia all because of the position that it now finds itself in with regard to the forthcoming election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Generalissimo Franco would have been very pleased with the second wave legislation in Western Australia. Trying to draw a bead on what that legislation means for the rest of Australia has been made very difficult. What we have seen in this country is a federal coalition opposition jettison all sorts of policies. They no longer believe in the GST. It is a bit like Faulty Towers: don't mention the war or the GST. Their 15th or 16th plan to effect a health system has had to be jettisoned. They basically support Medicare. They would not touch any of these areas in social welfare. They basically adopt the same strategic approach in defence.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that today for the first time we have seen those on the opposition benches get excited. Their existentialist nerve jangled away as they suddenly saw the real enemy—again, the workers of Australia—and how they could have these attitudes which they have had for decades on industrial relations.

It is all in code. Those opposite talk about freeing up the labour market. That is code for bringing in draconian legislation to control workers. We know on the record that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) supported the first wave of legislation in Western Australia. But it was only today that I understood he supported the second wave. On the Sattler program, he said, `There are features of the legislation which coincide with ours.' We do not know whether he is telling the truth because he will not publish his policy. He has worked it out. He said that he has all the details done but that he will not publish them. So we do not know whether his public comment today about the Kierath legislation in Western Australia being similar to federal Liberal Party policy is true because they do not have the fortitude to debate those issues in public. They do not have confidence in their policy to be able to sustain it in a public debate.
We know that Mr Howard has been going around the country talking to business groups about it. Here is a quote from Mr Howard from last September:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the greatest advantages of my having laid out an industrial relations program over such a long period of time is that if I win the election nobody can deny I have a mandate to change industrial relations.

In other words, Mr Howard is saying that he will return to his old policies. He is going back to the sorts of policies he espoused as a shadow minister under John Hewson when going into the last election. He is going back to all his old tricks.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's approach to state and federal industrial relations legislation fails to acknowledge the fundamental economic and social benefits that come from social cohesion. A fair and equitable industrial relations system is a necessary precondition to an efficient one. Fairness and equity are essential for commitment to participating effectively at the enterprise level. There are obviously significant broader ramifications for productivity growth and inflation and thus for macro-economic policy and employment. The whole economic and social fabric is threatened by conflictive, anti-worker approaches to industrial relations policy that the Liberal Party has consistently adopted at the federal and state levels, marked most by Western Australia and Victoria.

A fractured industrial relations environment in a national setting would reverse all the gains made towards a participative culture encouraged by the accord process. That has delivered a threshold cut to the rate of inflation to less than three per cent over three years compared with 11 per cent when we came into office in 1983. There has been a dramatic fall in the number of strikes, from an average of over 590 working days lost per year under the coalition to much less than half that on average since 1983 under us. This year has seen the lowest number of strikes and days lost since 1940. For 55 years, under our guidance it is the lowest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Western Australia has got the best record.

—Senator Crane says that Western Australia is the best. Why do you need all this draconian legislation if you are not just returning to your old prejudices and hates? That is what you are doing. The demons of the past are driving the Liberal Party on this matter. At least you have been a consistent draconian advocate over the years.

PARA.TAB: So we have the lowest number of days lost in 55 years. In the macro-economic settings, which have allowed a very healthy and sustained economic and employment growth over the last few years, over two million jobs have been created since 1983. That was partly because of the industrial relations environment created by this government. We should remember that these social and economic achievements cannot be achieved within the sort of conflictive approach that coalition parties always take to these matters. John Howard consistently supports the antagonistic policy which is reflected in Western Australia and Victoria.

Victoria is relevant because the Court government has modelled a lot of its legislation on the Victorian legislation. This is what Mr Kennett, the Premier of Victoria, said on the subject of the Victorian industrial relations system—and you should listen if you do not know. Do I have to remind you what the Liberal Party in Victoria, your colleagues, has done? This is the one with minimum wages only and no compensation for loss of overtime rates, penalty rates or holiday leave loading, even though the court has knocked over the latter one.

Workers in Victoria have been leaving in droves to go to federal awards, but not under Western Australian legislation. If you leave, your union gets tossed out. If you return, the government minister allocates which union you will go to. That is under your system. Have a look at the system of fines under the ballot thing and see how draconian it is.

This is miserable anti-worker legislation. It does give you a thrill to do this because you achieve a lifetime ambition of kicking workers. That is what the coalition, the Liberal Party, enjoys. The true Liberal Party comes out. It is very hard to get a measure on the federal Liberal Party's policy. The one area where there is absolute concurrence is in the federal and state areas of industrial relations. That is the one area where we are entitled to deduce how Liberals would behave in power if they are going to hide their policies. We have seen them in action in Western Australia and Victoria.

Mr Kennett said, `A federal Liberal Party would implement the policies which his government has tried to implement.' He also said that once the coalition was elected the Victorian employees would have nowhere to go. In other words, an industrial relations iron curtain would come down over the four southern states—the AFL states. You would have them trapped by federal and state legislation. Glory be, wouldn't you enjoy that? Would you not enjoy bringing in legislation that had them trapped? Are you going to put guards on the Murray River to stop them going to New South Wales and Queensland to escape your laws? Are you going to go that far?

Why are you so anti-worker? What drives you to a sort of crypto-corporate state approach to these matters? Every time you get into power you have to bring in this sort of legislation. I will tell you what it is: it is the demons of the past. It is a fact that the workers and trade unionists of this country have not supported you. You think by kicking workers you will somehow get some sort of sycophantic reaction from the employers. The fact is a lot of them do not like your industrial relations. A lot of employers in Victoria and Western Australia just see it as another way of ripping apart the social fabric. They just see it as another way of doing bad business in a state. You cannot help yourselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still want the masters and servants act, do you?

—Senator Crane has come out and talked about the first and second wave as being reforms. What a code word. What a euphemism that is. It is draconian legislation meant to destroy the trade union movement in this country. That is what it means and what Mr Kennett means when he says, `There will be no escape.'

PARA.TAB: Do you support that? Do you support Mr Kennett's comments on that matter? No response, of course. You opposite want to build an industrial relations iron curtain around the four states you control. You can only do it by winning federal power, having a secret industrial relations agenda that you will not put on the table. You are too scared to put your industrial relations policy on the table to let the public look at it and analyse it. You are too scared of criticism, too scared of a critique of it to be able to put it on the table, so you hide your policy away like mangy dogs. We know what you are up to because your state governments have done it. They have blown the whistle on you. They have brought in this sort of legislation that you would like to bring in federally. In the process of which, they have revealed what John Howard and his cohorts would like to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —If anything was needed to confirm that the phoney election campaign is under way it was Senator Robert Ray's contribution. I really saw the sabres rattling there. We almost saw the Maginot line being drawn around the AFL states as an appeal to patriotism. Senator Crane is equally guilty referring to the masters and servants act and trying to stir up some sort of past ideologies.

PARA.TAB: This is really about the phoney campaign being conducted and the extreme positions being delineated. The war is about to be waged. The people of Australia are already sick of it. They do not want to hear the rhetoric anymore. They do not want to know any more that emphasises the mess that could result if these extremities are followed. The answer is not in the extremities that are being delineated by both participants in this phoney campaign. The tactics that are being used by both sides, including today's union blockade and whether there is any honesty and accountability on the part of the political leaders involved regarding what they are saying and doing about industrial relations policy, are really what the public is looking for.

The Australian Democrats do not support the use of excessive industrial action to achieve inappropriate results. However, unlike the coalition, we recognise that the withdrawal of labour by workers is a legitimate response when negotiation falls down and the other party is being unreasonable. Clearly, in the Western Australian situation today, negotiation has broken down with the Court government and Minister Kierath being anything but reasonable.

I am not entirely persuaded that today's blockade is the best means to resolve the problem. The problem is entirely of the making of the Western Australian government. Here we have a government responding to a non-existent problem of alleged union militancy with an excessive and extreme package of laws for which they have no electoral mandate. Worse, the package of laws breaches several international ILO conventions and stands Australia up for world condemnation. In the same way Senator Crane is concerned about our international reputation, we should be concerned about it.

It is in the national interest for Australian industrial relations, and the Australian public at large, for our industrial relations to be conducted as amicably as possible. This can only happen with both unions and employers feeling they are part of the equation. Policies which seek to marginalise unions cannot achieve industrial harmony, just as policies which seek to dictate to employers what they can and cannot do cannot foster meaningful negotiations.

Over the 13-year life of the various accords, Australia appears to have dragged itself out of the quagmire of unnecessary confrontations in the industrial relations system towards a more consensual one. I cannot say that we have reached that end point. The accord process does have its warts. The processes which exist at the moment still can be described as cumbersome but at least we can point to some successes and to the possibility of the industrial relations system working.

David Edwards from the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry recently noted that Australian workers are very wary of change and reform and that change is needed to hasten slowly at a rate at which the employees are comfortable. Plenty of other major employers have given similar messages about the rate of change. I would hasten to add that at the moment there is no clamouring, no massive need for dramatic and radical IR reform in this country. The only people calling for it are the ideologues on the right.

We even have conservative commentators, as we have heard earlier today, such as Professor Judith Sloan, who said that the Western Australian reforms go too far too quickly. The Court government has failed to demonstrate a valid reason for the scope of its changes. In my view, and worse than that, it has also failed to demonstrate a valid mandate for the package it has introduced.

In the months leading up to its election in February 1993, electors in WA were bombarded with advertisements from born again, benign, moderate Richard Court assuring them that this was not Victoria and he was not Jeff Kennett. He was right. He is worse than Jeff Kennett. He has exceeded his mandate for policy change and gone well beyond what the WA electorate elected him to do. In doing so, he has followed the path already blazed by Mr Kennett and Dean Brown in promising moderation but delivering reactionary extremism in industrial relations policy. He might have also damaged the election chances of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, who is trying to persuade the electorate that, after 10 years of calling for radical industrial relations reform, he has changed his mind and he now supports mild and moderate tinkering.

Anyone in Victoria, South Australia and now Western Australia who believes that must believe in Santa Claus. If Mr Howard and his promises of new-found moderation on industrial relations are to be believed, he must come out and condemn Premier Court and Minister Kierath for misleading the electors of WA about their IR plans. By condoning their barefaced dishonesty during the election campaign, he leaves himself wide open to charges that he will do the same.

As far as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is concerned, as I indicated earlier, I can understand the anger of workers in WA, but I do not believe that today's blockade will go anywhere near fixing the problem. The Prime Minister should not condone it in any way and should not give it any support whatsoever. The solution lies in bringing the WA workers under the protection of federal awards. Recently the support of the Democrats led to the inclusion in the Industrial Relations Act of the escape clause to federal awards for Victorian workers. Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:
That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Kernot moving an amendment to the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: At the end of motion add: "and the failure of the Leader of the Opposition to condemn the West Australian Premier for going to the people in an election campaign promising moderate industrial relations policies and then implementing the most radical and divisive industrial relations laws in Australia".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have reached a new height today in the Labor litany of lies. I think this is a very sad day. The amendment to the urgency motion that the Australian Democrats have moved makes the situation even worse. The motion moved by Senator Crane states:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The failure of the Prime Minister to condemn the political and economic blockade of Western Australia by supporting the Trades & Labor Council ahead of the national interest.

It will be interesting to listen to the two Labor senators from Western Australia who will be speaking on this motion and see whether or not they defend the right of their constituents to access goods and services today. As I said earlier today, the fact of the matter is that this is all about the lead up to an election where the Labor government is encouraging its Labor mates within the trade union movement to ensure there is as much industrial disputation as is conceivably possible prior to the next election.

PARA.TAB: It is getting to the stage where we will find the Labor Party saying that every baby in the street will be pitch forked, put in a pile at the end of the street and burnt. Before the last election in Western Australia the Labor government, led by forgetful Dr Lawrence, embarked on a scare campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?

—Dr Lawrence, the one who cannot remember anything. Before she was defeated as Premier she warned voters that the coalition would, if elected, abolish awards. Let me tell you that not one award has been abolished. She said also that the state Liberal government would reduce wages by 25 per cent. PARA.TAB: The Labor leader at the time, Dr Forgetful Carmen Lawrence, said also that a Liberal government would shut down the Industrial Relations Commission. What has happened? Quite the contrary. The Industrial Relations Commission has been strengthened by the state Liberal government. She also said that the work force would be forced to sign or resign. What has happened? That is the fear campaign that Dr Forgetful Carmen Lawrence absolutely scandalously perpetrated prior to the last state election. That is what this Labor government did prior to the last federal election. That is what they are going to do from now to the next election. They will not only ensure that there is as much industrial disputation as they can possibly manage but also delve into the depths of the lie barrel to make sure that as many lies as possible are told about policies that they claim we do not have. How can they talk about the policies that they claim we do not have and what they are going to do to the workers when on one hand they say we do not have policies and on the other hand they say that this is what is going to happen?

The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Beazley, says that the reforms in Western Australia are unfair. Maybe Senator Chris Evans or Senator McKiernan, as two Western Australian senators who do not care what happens to Western Australia today, could explain to the Senate what is unfair about giving workers a secret ballot instead of their being bullied by union leaders into a show of hands. What is unfair about allowing union members, not the union leaders, the IRC and the minister to decide what coverage they prefer—federal or state awards?

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the teachers and the police; you lost them both.

—Senator Evans said, `What about the teachers?' What about the teachers? Under the Labor government in Western Australia, teachers in 1989 had 23,600 working days lost. That is education under a Labor government. Last year under the Liberal government there were 100. You created that situation.

PARA.TAB: I will continue with Mr Beazley's statement that the reforms are unfair. What is unfair about restricting union officials from entering work places unless they are on legitimate and relevant business instead of the way in which they operate today? Regardless of whether there are union members on a premises or not they barge in and demand to see the books. That will no longer be possible and they know it. What is unfair about ensuring that political donations can only be made with consent of members? Shock, horror! That is in contrast with what the Labor Party wants. They want to make sure that they get back their $2.2 billion that they give to the ACTU. That is what this is about. They think that is unfair. We think it is the right of employees to decide whether to contribute through their membership to a political party. What is unfair about giving employees the right to direct superannuation contributions to the fund of their choice? I do not think that is unfair. What is unfair about making unions more accountable? Absolutely nothing, unless you are a member of the Labor Party.

This is way in which this Labor Party is going off the rails. This is way they are going to deceive the people of Australia through to the next election. They do not care about what happens to the people. Let us face it. The state Labor leader, Mr McGinty, declared that the Western Australian second wave of industrial relation reforms would be `a major battleground for the federal election'. Even he is aware of the strategy and the tactic that this Labor government is using—the fear campaign, the lie campaign, all a regurgitation of what happened prior to the 1993 state and federal elections. That does not matter. The truth has been sacrificed on the altar of political expediency.

That is what they are all about, that the changes give more freedom of choice, and not freedom of choice to the union bosses. That is what they are worried about. The fact of the matter is that people, even the hard line unionists of the Pilbara iron ore mines, have signed workplace agreements. Of course, they would never have done that if Senator Cook was still up there telling them what to do and encouraging industrial disputation, as he did as a union boss.

The figures have been turned around by the state Liberal government, in comparison with what forgetful Dr Carmen Lawrence did when she was premier, and all her predecessors. Earlier today I cited the figures on the way in which industrial disputes have been reversed. That is, in 1989, under a Labor government, industrial disputes peaked at 47,800 total working days lost compared with, last year under the Liberals, 1,100. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day for me as a Western Australian senator to realise what is happening back in the state that we represent and to the people that we represent in this place. We see thousands of workers giving up the only thing that they have got—their wages, their salaries—to protest against the most draconian set of industrial relations policies this country has seen for years.

PARA.TAB: There have been some statistics bandied about today in this chamber about the good industrial relations record of Western Australia. I will look at those statistics and examine them with great care and in great detail because they do not, to my mind, measure up to what has been happening in Western Australia all throughout 1995.

The teachers have been engaged in a continuous industrial relations campaign instigated by the government. The nurses are also being targeted by the government. Indeed, we are now seeing the government attempting to impose a second wave of industrial relations legislation on the working people of Western Australia. But it is not only the working people of Western Australia that have been targeted; it is the whole of the state that has been targeted. I think the West Australian newspaper in a series of articles it did yesterday summed up the real dangers in what is going on. On page 5, under the headline `All agree big jobs at risk' the trade union movement, government officials and industry are all agreeing that what Mr Graham Kierath is about in Western Australia is putting the state's economy at grave risk, not only this year but for the future. It is causing enormous damage to us.

The state government made no bones, made no secret of their views on industrial relations before they went to the 1993 election. Nigel Wilson, in an article in today's Australian summed it up reasonably well. I will quote part of it:

The Liberal and National Coalition made no secret when campaigning for the 1993 election that it wanted to change the labour relations framework. But against strident ALP attacks, West Australian Premier Richard Court maintained he was not Jeff Kennett, and Victoria's industrial revolution would not be adopted in Western Australia.

Indeed, it wasn't. The reality was far worse for West Australian unions, which described the first legislation—which promoted workplace agreements instead of industrial awards—as the most draconian in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is a minister of the Crown, Mr Kierath, doing this? Why is he putting the economy of Western Australia and the economy of Australia at risk with this draconian legislation which is opposed not only by the trade union movement in Western Australia, the trade union movement nationally and each of the labour councils but also by the employers? The opposition is even coming from within the Western Australian government. The ideologues who have control of the Western Australian coalition government have the numbers to ensure that Mr Kierath's ideology will prevail and ensure that the state's economy will continue to be put at risk and that working people's livelihood will continue to be threatened.

PARA.TAB: After the effects of today's 24 hours of industrial activity there is still time to recover, if the minister will step back a little and remove the blinkers that are focusing him down one right wing path.
