Give working people in that great state, Western Australia, a chance.

TALK.START.PARA: —This blockade of Western Australia today would be the most extreme exercise in stupidity that I have seen. Mr McGinty, for the first time since he has been Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia, has made a sensible decision in denouncing this blockade of Western Australia. Western Australia is the only state contributing to the welfare of Australia at the moment.

PARA.TAB: This government has been like a snake in a corner since last May at least. There is only one way to deal with a snake in a corner. Give it the scatter gun and get rid of it. Since the budget, when they came out with a supposed $750 million surplus, they have been looking for windows of opportunity for an election. That lasted for about a week, if it lasted for that long. That aura lasted for a week. Then we had something else and then something else. They were looking for an opportunity to have an election and something to run on. They have nothing. At every corner they have been overcome. They have not got the opportunity.

They say, `We will kick up industrial relations in Western Australia.' Western Australia has the best industrial relations record since the Court government was elected. The Court government, through its policies, has done something to relieve the unemployment situation since it has been elected. What did the Labor Party do? They got on this bandwagon, aided and abetted by Mr Laurie Brereton and aided and abetted by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is no good saying the Prime Minister is neutral in this case. Last week he was in favour of the blockade. This week he reckons he is neutral. If you are the leader of a country which is under siege you cannot afford to be neutral. You cannot be neutral when any part of the Commonwealth is being attacked. The Prime Minister should have come out and condemned this blockade of Western Australia, which is the only state contributing to the welfare of Australia, just like Mr McGinty has. For the first time in my life, I will give Mr McGinty credit for something he has done.

The Labor Party wants to create a situation. They are trying to make Australians believe that we attack the workers. It comes up every election with statements that we do not like the workers. That is a total lie and will be shown to be a total lie as the election nears.

Western Australia is the only state that is really contributing. Australia had a total deficit of some $28 billion last financial year. Western Australia runs a surplus of $11 billion a year. I say that for the benefit of those two senators on the other side who do not know. That works out to almost $1 billion a month. That is the trade surplus from Western Australia. If you divide that amount by 250, which is about the number of working days in a year, it comes out at about $44 million a day net surplus that Western Australia supplies to Australia. If it were not for Western Australia, the deficit for Australia would be over $3.25 billion a month. This blockade is doing at least $44 million damage today. It is at least that amount, because that is a net figure. The expenses will probably keep continuing. The income ceases. That is what you are doing to Australia, not only Western Australia.

We lead Australia in everything. We lead Australia in attacking unemployment. We have done that. We lead Australia in mining income. We lead Australia in primary industry income. We lead Australia in almost everything. You are doing damage that cannot be undone. It is all very well to say that the wheels will start rolling again tomorrow and we will regain that, but that $44 million is gone.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's gone—gone forever.

—It's gone forever. Imagine what you could do with $44 million. It has gone out the window. You won't get that back. It will run into tomorrow and the day after and the day after, because when industry closes down it takes a good while to get it moving again. That is what you have done to Western Australia. You should be condemned for it.

PARA.TAB: Western Australia produces 80 per cent of Australia's gold. How much of that production ceased today? Last season we produced 5.7 million tonnes of wheat or 62 per cent of Australia's total crop. How much of that is not going to be shipped out of Western Australia today? You tell me. Western Australia does all of that with only 10.6 per cent of Australia's population. We produce 27 per cent of Australia's export income.

Those two senators opposite who support the blockade of Western Australia have the temerity to come in here and say that they represent Western Australia. They should be ashamed to say that. They certainly do not. They are cutting their own throats.

I wonder about the situation we have in Western Australia today. This federal government obviously cannot manage the industrial relations portfolio. How can they hope to manage the rest of the country? Will the Labor Party take responsibility for the problems in Perth today, with traffic lights out left, right and centre, with the weather they have had? Union members are not allowed to fix the lights. Will you take responsibility for what may happen tonight? I certainly hope you do.

TALK.START.PARA: —One in three out today.
—One in three out in the west today. What answers do you have? This government stands condemned. As I said before, Mr Keating—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose Senator Crane's motion. In doing so, I must say I am incredulous at the argument that has been placed before us today. Essentially, the Liberal Party's argument is that the second wave legislation in Western Australia is all part of some federal ALP plot to put industrial relations on the agenda. The simple way to get this issue off the agenda is for them to withdraw the legislation. It is a Liberal state government initiative. It is the most draconian and anti-worker legislation seen in this country. It amounts to a fundamental attack on the rights of workers to organise themselves, to collectively bargain and to be represented by trade unions. It is in the Liberals' hands to take the issue off the agenda.

PARA.TAB: Far from being a Labor plot, the Labor Party expresses sympathy for workers in Western Australia. It understands the position they have taken in withdrawing their labour. It is the only way they are able to demonstrate to the state government the seriousness of the issue and their deep concern. To that extent, we understand the position adopted in Western Australia today.

It is on the Court government's head that it has come to this. It is a shame that they have been driven by the ideologies of Mr Court and of Mr Kierath. I suppose I must take some blame for that because, in a former life as a trade union official, I used to inspect Mr Kierath's time and wages records when he was a contract cleaning employer. I must take my share of the blame for his paranoia about trade unions having access to time and wages records.

I want to put on the record some of the key issues in this debate rather than carry on the sort of rhetorical debate we have had so far. The fact is that the first wave of industrial legislation introduced by the Court government was aimed at introducing individual contracts into the workplaces of Western Australia. Mr Howard has endorsed the approach adopted in Western Australia in the first wave and today went further and seemed to endorse the second wave as well.

The purpose of the first wave of industrial relations legislation in Western Australia was to undermine and replace awards with individual contracts. The whole direction of the legislation sought to have awards replaced by workers signing individual contracts with their employer. The legislation removed the role of unions in that process, made the process secret, avoided any scrutiny of that process and ensured that the employer negotiated one on one with each of his employees.

The claim by the Liberal Party is that that provides choice and freedom to the employees but the reality, of course, is quite different. There have been two features to the reality in Western Australia. The first is that, in highly unionised well-paid areas of the work force, employers have essentially sought to buy out trade unionism. They have offered workers individual contracts that provide better conditions than the award and have bought the loyalty of the work force with a higher total package on individual contracts. They have in a sense bought the unions out of the system. That was anticipated by the trade union movement. The trade union movement recognises that it has to have new strategies to deal with that sort of approach. Eventually, I think it will regain membership in these areas where individual contracts have been used to encourage workers to leave trade unions.

The second tenet of the legislation has been for low paid and largely unskilled workers to be exploited by having individual contracts offered to them by their employers. These contracts are made in secrecy. There is no public scrutiny of these individual contracts. It is quite clear that those contracts have been used in many industries—particularly with the young, with women and with unskilled workers—to drive down the package of pay and conditions that is available to those workers. A good deal of evidence about those individual workplace agreements has been coming to light. At a later stage I will present some of those examples to the Senate.

But if anyone is in any doubt about what that legislation does in the first wave, I want to put it on the record once again. The Trades and Labour Council of Western Australia obtained a legal opinion on the impact of that first wave of the legislation from Ian Viner QC, a former Liberal minister. He provided a very thorough legal opinion on what that first wave of industrial relations reform legislation did. I quote part of the legal opinion of Ian Viner QC:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation does not protect prospective employees who wish to be employed pursuant to an award rather than a workplace agreement in circumstances where the prospective employer requires that they enter into a workplace agreement as a precondition to employment.
There you have Ian Viner, a former Liberal minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —For industrial relations—

—A former Liberal minister for industrial relations providing his legal opinion that, in fact, the choice or the freedom that Mr Howard endorses does not occur; that employees are open to exploitation; that they are in an unfair bargaining position; and that the individual contracts can be used by employers in a very unbalanced and unfair way to drive down wages and conditions and make employees agree to those conditions. The legal opinion goes much further into all the examples and circumstances that that legislation permits. A former Liberal minister has made it clear that the system that Mr Howard and the opposition support is about exploitation of workers. That is what individual contracts is doing and that is what Mr Howard has tied the opposition to by endorsing that first wave of industrial relations legislation in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Mr Reith has gone on to try to provide some protection for the Liberal Party in terms of its industrial relations policy by claiming that he will support a no disadvantage test and some basic minimum conditions of employment. It is very educational to look at what the minimum conditions of employment in Western Australia provide—in the sense that this is the example of industrial relations policy that Mr Howard has endorsed. When one looks at those minimum conditions of employment in Western Australia, one finds that one can drive a truck through those conditions. It provides, for instance, that casual employees are not entitled to minimum conditions of employment.

What we are seeing in WA is a whole range of employees being offered regular weekly work under workplace contracts provided that they are classified as casuals. This means that they are not entitled to the protection of the minimum conditions of employment act and they are not protected from having their wages, their hours, their annual leave, et cetera protected. Provided they are classified as a casual employee, even though they might have been working there for years, they get no protection.

Equally, WA workers get no protection by way of enforcement. Mr Kierath has written to the miscellaneous workers union in Western Australia indicating that the workplace commissioner, the supposed watchdog of these minimum conditions, is not obliged to alter any agreement which does not provide the minimum conditions. The commissioner is required to advise the employer and the employee that they do not meet the minimum conditions but he will register an agreement that does not meet the minimums.

So this is the Liberal protection: this is the protection they offer the workers. The loopholes through the minimum conditions in Western Australia are so wide as to give no protection at all to a worker offered a workplace agreement by an employer. There is no recourse; there is no union protection; there is no protection provided by the workplace commissioner in terms of their rights; and it seems that there are no minimum conditions of employment. If you are a casual employee, you are not entitled to anything other than bereavement leave, which is not much comfort.

Another educational example of the minimums that apply in Western Australia relates to the minimum wage. The Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission is now required to recommend to the state minister the appropriate minimum weekly wage. It recently recommended that it be increased from $301.10 to $325.40. Mr Kierath, the state industrial relations minister—who has given himself the power to set minimum wages in Western Australia—rejected the industrial commission's recommendation, rejected the umpire's recommendation, and fixed the new minimum wage at $317.10. This is some 30 per cent less than the increase recommended. He claimed in parliament that his actions were justified by a report from a Professor David Plowman, whom he had employed as an industrial relations expert to provide advice. Yet what we find out subsequently is that Professor Plowman recommended that the minimum weekly wage should be no lower than $330—even higher than the minimum which the industrial commission recommended.

When you give the Liberal Party the power to set minimums, first, they make sure they are not enforceable and, second, when it comes to the minimum wage they will not accept the industrial commission's recommendation; they strike a lower rate. This is the same old Liberal Party that argued for $3 an hour and who argued for no protection for workers. They support individual contracts in Western Australia because that allows exploitation of workers, exploitation of the young, exploitation of the unskilled and exploitation of women—exploitation of those who have no bargaining power. It is sign or resign; it is sign or face the sack. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a close look at the title of today's urgency motion. From my old debating rules, it sprang to mind that you look at the meaning of the words that are there, and the words that stood out on the paper were `national interest'. The question I asked myself was: how does the opposition identify national interest? It seems quite obvious here that the interests of the majority of workers in Australia are not how the opposition defines national interest.

PARA.TAB: We are not talking about a small number of people. If we are talking about Western Australia, we are talking about a vast number of people who are, and will be, affected by the coalition's industrial relations law. So it seems quite clear that, if it is about the immediate short-term profits of corporations, then that is the definition of national interest we are looking at here instead of looking at the medium- and long-term benefits of the country and the people who live in that country.

What are we finding out today? Is the opposition suggesting—shock, horror!—that we deny workers their right to strike or withhold their labour? Any suggestion of a requirement of six weeks in respect of an aggrievement is a denial of workers' right to strike or withhold their labour. Is it indicative of the real nature of the coalition's industrial relations policy? I say it is.

The right to withhold labour is seen internationally as a basic human right, because the denial of this right is a sign of enforced labour or wage slavery. Those people who fight against this right will say, `Yes, but you have a choice.' But what are the choices if you are on a sign or resign contract or a sign or be sacked contract?

The coalition has focused on deregulating the labour market and this has resulted in workers being forced to compete against each other in the reduction of their own wages and conditions. The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—In accordance with provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

EMPHASIS.TAB: Report No. 4 of 1995-96—Efficiency Audit—Department of Social Security—Regional Office Resourcing and Benefit Processing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is one of a series of audit reports by the Australian National Audit Office. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you are aware, the Audit Office has been the subject of much discussion in this place, particularly about the level of resourcing it has been allocated and the extent of its independence. Undoubtedly, there is a great need for the Audit Office and I for one have been a great defender of its activities.

PARA.TAB: Briefly, I want to note that, clearly, this audit into the Department of Social Security regional office resourcing and benefit processing will be of benefit to the department itself. The fact is that a very large amount of money is involved in these regional offices. As this report reveals, in 1994-95 the salary and administrative costs for regional offices were about $560 million, of which the great bulk, $460 million, was salary costs alone.

The Audit Office found—and I just highlight a couple of their findings—that there is an appreciable scope for improving the allocation of resources across the regional office network; client services could be improved if the time of operations staff in the regional office is directed more to quality service delivery; and there are gains to be made from identifying and moving towards internal best practice.

It makes this particular finding, which is of some concern, that client service in some offices falls well below Department of Social Security standards. Another finding, which should be highlighted, is that there is scope for improvement in the collection of information from clients and that the key performance indicators of regional offices need to be better focused on results required.

One problem here is that the Audit Office was not able to independently assess—I notice a split infinitive there; so I direct that to the attention of the Auditor-General—whether regional offices are appropriately resourced as DSS could not provide the data needed by the Audit Office on the full range of work loads. I must say that does seem to be quite surprising.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only had this Auditor-General's report No. 4 of 1995-96 for some very short while. I think it is an absolutely damning report. Senator Richardson, when he was Minister for Social Security, stood in this place over and over again and told us that the Department of Social Security was trim, taut and terrific and that there were no savings to be made. When we said there were savings to be made, he accused us of wanting to cut services and benefits.

PARA.TAB: We see in this report today something in the vicinity, conservatively, of about $30 million to $80 million that could be saved by improvements in administration and best practice within the Department of Social Security. The Audit Office tells us that if the Department of Social Security just looked at best practice within their own regional offices—not the best of the regional offices, but the top quarter—and applied those practices in the worst offices, you would get savings. If you actually introduced best practice from outside, you may get even greater savings. Enormous savings are to be made just by analysing the best practice undertaken within regional offices.

We see in the Auditor-General's report information that there are three different systems for processing benefits: family benefits, pensions and unemployment benefits. So if you get in the wrong queue and you give all the information, they say, `You are in the wrong queue, go to the next queue', and you have to give all the information again. What does that do to staff time on the other side?

I think an estimate has been made that if one minute per staff member per day was saved on bad practice, it would be worth $1 million a year—one minute per day! I am not saying that the Department of Social Security staff do not work hard enough but if they worked one minute per day smarter, because they were trained a different way or the processes were redone, there would be savings—and you would get better client services.

All the way through this report you see the Audit Office saying not only would there be savings but there would be improvements of an order of magnitude in client services for the number of people who go in there and wait in queues, or as someone I was associated with who was applying for a benefit was told, `Come back on another day because the person who deals with that is not here.' It did not matter that the person had driven 40 kilometres to get to the Department of Social Security office—`Come back on another day.'

Why was there not someone there? Because there are three different systems and regional officers are trained, apparently, in only one system. So somebody deals with pensions, somebody deals with another issue and because the information technology is not adequate, up-to-date and coping with the developments in social security, staff cannot be trained or are not trained to deal with cross-benefits. When I said that the client had driven 40 kilometres to apply for a benefit, they did find somebody to deal with that client and I give credit to that regional office.

But through this Auditor-General's report time and time again we see examples of savings. The Auditor-General's Office considers that there is a five per cent to 10 per cent salary saving in benefit processing times. Senator Baume just mentioned that there was $560 million of salaries. I stand to be corrected—as I said, I have only just got this report—but it is estimated that 30 per cent of salaries is spent on processing and there is an estimated five per cent to 10 per cent saving there if there is an improvement in the time spent on processing claims. That is about $5 million. All the way through this you see $5 million here, another $1 million there and $35 million here. And I wonder—there are lots of things—what all this money could be used for that is actually wasted in inefficient processes, inefficient and outdated information technology and inefficient means of processing benefits.

The other thing that the Audit Office has highlighted is that it is unable to determine overall workloads in regional offices because the necessary information was not available and could not be extracted from the Department of Social Security. Had the information been available, some comparisons could have been made. There could have been further savings.

This report looks at work practices and IT across regional offices. If we translated that back to the area offices, I presume there would be savings—but perhaps not of the same magnitude. Not long ago former Senator Richardson came into this chamber and said, `There are no more savings to be made. You people want to rip the heart out of social security in Australia. That is what you want to do, you heartless people.' This government has had 13 years to get it right. If this government had been more businesslike in its approach and had paid attention to what it is doing rather than spending its time focusing on the opposition, millions of dollars would have been saved in an area like social security. These savings could have either repaid some of our foreign debt or been used to provide other services. But no, we have these inefficiencies from a tired Labor government which is unable to drag itself out of its complacency.

It is interesting that we no longer receive press releases from the Audit Office. I suppose the news is so bad so often that the government tries to hide it. The press gallery is not going to receive a press release. Some keen journalist has to go through the red and find that the Auditor-General's report has been tabled. The press will be interested in this one. We see that millions and millions of dollars can be saved. The government cannot come and say to us that because there are savings to be made the money will have to be taken out of services.

This government needs to have worked smarter and to have been more efficient. No wonder the Australian people are looking to an alternative government. No wonder the Australian people are fed up. We see report after report like this. We see money being lost on ANL and money being lost on Midford-Paramount. Month after month we see areas identified where there could be savings. The amounts involved are not puny. We see $5 million going on a contract to promote changes in the disability reform package to a company that was balance sheet insolvent. Every time we turn around we see another example of this government's inefficiency and tired old approach to management.

When I look across to the other side of this chamber I think I know why. Those opposite have never managed anything. When they do try to manage something—like Stephen Loosley, who has run away—they make a failure of it. They owe millions.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is being paid well.

—Yes, he is being paid well. I think the government should levy his salary to pay back the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales. Whatever those opposite touch turns into disaster. Very few of them have ever had real management experience, and that shows in this sort of report. Minister after minister has failed to address the problems associated with this department. DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS (1995-96 BUDGET MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: This year marks the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II. A very successful program of commemorative events has taken place as Australia Remembers. This program has touched the hearts of Australians of all ages, but the remembrance has been a special one for the veteran community and for those with close links with that community.

The veterans' affairs 1995 budget package reflects the government's response to the changing needs of the veteran community through the introduction of a range of simplified and expanded services. This bill contains amendments necessary to implement some of the budget elements. Further bills, covering the remaining budget initiatives requiring legislative amendments, will be introduced shortly. Other measures do not require legislation.
Before I turn to the matters contained in this bill, Mr President, I would like to mention some of the non-legislative budget measures.

In June this year, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs announced an aged care policy for the veteran community, As time goes by: continuing the commitment. This policy sets out the future directions for care of the veteran community for the next five to ten years. The policy also includes the outcomes of the joint ministerial task force on veterans aged care services that the minister established, in conjunction with his colleague, the Minister for Human Services and Health, last year to improve veterans access to aged care services. In response to the recommendations of this task force, the government is introducing a five-year program to assist ex-service organisations, where necessary, to upgrade, replace or relocate their aged care facilities. This program will be complemented by a four-year community care seeding grants program to improve the range and availability of community services in areas of demonstrated need where there is a high veteran population.

Another major initiative increases funding for research targeted to the health needs of the veteran community. A number of priority research areas will be identified each year to maintain the focus on veteran-related issues. These arrangements will ensure that the health areas of most concern to veterans can be researched by the best scientists available in each field.

Mr President, to mark this year of remembrance, the government has extended air travel entitlement to Australia's three surviving Victoria Cross medal recipients for the remainder of their lives. The government is also contributing to special commemorative projects, such as the joint Australia-Thailand project for a memorial park centred on Hellfire Pass and nearby features of the railway that was constructed by allied POW labour during World War II, and the project to erect a memorial on Anzac Parade in Canberra to commemorate those who lost their lives in the Korean War.

Other measures announced by the government include payment of nursing home costs for Australian former prisoners of war, access to chiropractic and osteopathic services by entitled veterans, war widows and war widowers. The delivery of health care has been simplified by reducing, from four to two, the different types of treatment entitlement cards which increases the entitlement of 140,000 veterans, war widows and war widowers to services.

Mr President, I now wish to refer to the features of this bill. The bill makes a number of reforms to the Defence Service Homes Act 1918. These reforms will allow increased responsiveness to the range of housing options now available to veterans and eligible dependants.

The bill will extend eligibility for defence service home loans to cover several different title arrangements. Assistance will be available for properties held as tenants-in-common, on a company title, or on a leasehold title. The inclusion of these property titles reflects current commercial practice.

I am pleased to advise that this bill will extend eligibility for a defence service home loan to full-time members of World War II women's services. For fifty years, former members of the World War II women's services who did not actually serve overseas during war time have been excluded from defence service homes benefits, unlike many of the male service volunteers. In taking the initiative to redress that situation, the government recognises the major contribution to the war effort made by thousands of female volunteers who joined the services on the same basis as their male counterparts.

Many veterans and others eligible for a defence service home loan find their housing needs change as they grow older. Retirement village or granny flat accommodation becomes the preferred arrangement for many who have difficulty living independently. The bill will increase flexibility in the use of the housing loan by allowing eligible persons to assign their loan entitlement to secure entry to a retirement village managed by an organisation which has, as its prime purpose, the provision of accommodation to veterans and veterans' widows. Assignment of the loan to provide a granny flat will also be available, provided that type of accommodation is appropriate to the needs of the individual.

In a move that will be particularly welcomed by the many individuals who have sought the change, the bill will extend the option to insure under the Defence Service Homes Insurance Scheme to all persons eligible under the Defence Service Homes Act, irrespective of whether they have received a defence service home loan on their home.

The bill makes other changes to the Defence service home loan arrangements to increase its flexibility, such as allowing portability of a loan with the interest rates and remaining term of the current loan, and introducing generic certificates of entitlement. The bill also provides for cancellation of payment of the loan subsidy after the death of both the eligible veteran and any surviving spouse.

Mr President, I now want to outline the changes the bill makes to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The bill clarifies aspects of pension eligibility provisions in relation to allotment for duty and service in an operational area.

As explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators, the legislation has been improved so that it leads a reader through the relevant provisions, and develops a clearer understanding of the relationship between those provisions. Before the Veterans' Entitlements Act commenced in 1986, the Repatriation Act 1920 set out the service requirements for both a service pension and a disability pension. This bill preserves the original intention and concepts from the Repatriation Act, that qualifying service for a service pension arose from incurring danger from hostile forces of the enemy in a theatre of war.

Since World War II, qualifying service has required service in the operational area to which the veteran was allotted. The bill also confirms this as the requirement for operational service that attracts the beneficial standard of proof for disability pension claims. The bill makes it clear that members of units allotted for duty in Korea, but who served only in Japan, have operational service.

The bill will also enable any excess payment of Social Security pensions and benefits received by a veteran's partner, that result from a retrospective grant or increase of disability pension, to be deducted from the lump sum arrears of disability pension. These new arrangements will result in a speedier payment of the balance of disability pension arrears.

Mr President, the bill makes a number of changes to eligibility for a partner service pension. Firstly, from 1 October 1995 a partner service pension will not be granted unless the partner is 50 years or older, or is caring for a dependent child, or is the partner of a veteran who receives the special rate of disability pension for total and permanent incapacity or for total blindness. Existing partner service pensioners will not be affected. This change is consistent with the government's Working Nation policy which highlights the need to encourage work force participation. Of course, those partners who are ineligible for a partner service pension will be able to test eligibility for another income support payment, such as a carer service pension, or from Social Security a partner allowance, disability support pension or other payment.

Secondly, the bill will enable those who qualify for a partner service pension to retain eligibility for that pension, even if the veteran loses payability of the age or invalidity service pension. Thirdly, a person, including a widow or a widower, will be eligible for a partner service pension if the person qualifies for an age pension and if their partner is, or was, a veteran with qualifying service.

The bill also limits the rate of service pension payable to a person who is a member of a couple to the partnered rate of pension, even though the other member of the couple may not be receiving a pension or benefit. Those partnered pensioners who are now receiving a higher rate of pension will not have their pension reduced as a result of this change.

Mr President, the bill makes a number of changes to the income support supplement. The government introduced the income support supplement from March this year. The purpose of this supplement is to allow war widows and widowers to receive their compensation and income support payment from one department, the Department of Veterans' Affairs. One of the changes will better target persons who could benefit from this single payment arrangement, by extending eligibility for the income support supplement to war widows and widowers who are partners of service or social security pensioners.
Another change will be the exclusion of war widow or widower's pension when calculating bereavement payments to surviving partners of income support supplement recipients.

Mr President, last year the government initiated major extensions of treatment and support services for veterans suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder around Australia. Many veterans have directly benefited from specialised in-patient services and many more have received counselling and support services from the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service. This bill now introduces automatic eligibility for post-traumatic stress disorder treatment. Early intervention in post-traumatic stress disorder cases greatly increases the likelihood of successful treatment outcomes. Younger veterans and other veterans of all ages and all conflicts, being now assured of access to treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder, will be encouraged to seek appropriate early treatment for psychiatric problems brought on by post-traumatic stress disorder.

Another reform being introduced in this bill will simplify access to services by some people. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will be able to issue a Seniors Health Card to certain widows and widowers and to non-illness separated spouses of veterans. This is not an extension of eligibility for the Seniors Health Card, as these people are otherwise eligible for a card from the Department of Social Security, but the changes will be of considerable convenience to those who may periodically lose and gain payability of a pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs.
In concluding, Mr President, I believe that this bill presents important measures that respond to the changing needs of the veteran community. I commend the bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Employment, Education and Training References Committee for inquiry and report on or before 23 November 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether the sale of Bond University, as one of a very small number of non-Government universities in Australia, to the University of Queensland, a public institution, would be in the national interest and, in particular, whether it would lead to a reduction in diversity and choice in Australian tertiary education.

This is really quite an important matter in so far as Australian higher education is concerned at the moment. It relates to the purchase or, it would seem, likely purchase by the University of Queensland of the Bond University property on the Gold Coast, with the hope that the University of Queensland would then be able to take over the Bond University as such.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would be well aware, there are very few non-government higher education institutions in Australia and, in a way, Bond is unique among the very few that do exist. It is a full fee-paying institution offering undergraduate degrees to Australian students, and provides an alternative to the government system which dominates the sector. It does not mean that either is necessarily better than the other, but it does offer some choice that otherwise would not exist.

Certainly, in its relatively short time of existence, Bond has built a community of past students and supporters who speak highly of the education product that it has delivered, and are very committed to the continuation of Bond as a separate and non-government institution. As you are also well aware, the property is controlled by Japanese banks as a result of collapses post the corporate excesses of the 1980s. They are wishing to recover some of the moneys that are owing, and they obviously have an interest in selling their asset to the highest bidder.

One of the bidders clearly was the University of Queensland, and they were successful. Whether they were the highest bidder I gather is the subject of some debate, but in any event it seems that they were higher than the group that represented Bond University as such. The situation now exists that Bond University remains under its control and as constituted in the Queensland legislation, but the property has been purchased by a public university which intends to take it over. It says that it intends to take it over as a private, fee paying alternative rather than totally subsume it within the public system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you against or in favour of the purchase?

—I would very much like to know what the government's attitude is. Will you tell me what the minister's attitude is? You have had 14 years in government. You have sat by and watched this occur without a word. If Minister Crean has given you a brief, then finally we might get on the public record the government's position. And that will be a useful start. It is a pity that you have not said it before.
—What is your position?

—Just be patient. We have expressed concerns about this issue. We have expressed concerns about the loss of diversity and choice by one of the very few non-government institutions being absorbed by a public institution. That is pretty clear cut. We have said that before. There is no secret in that. Because of that loss of diversity and choice, a whole lot of other issues arise. For example, who is funding the Queensland university in this purchase? What guarantees are there that it will remain as a private institution? Will there be further cost to the public in the purchase? They are all issues that I think are vitally important to the public.

PARA.TAB: To make a start in trying to find the answers to some of these questions the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee, under the able leadership of Senator Tierney, has been conducting an internal inquiry, a private inquiry. That is no doubt useful to the committee members, but it does not help the balance of the parliament or the public at large to become aware of the consequences of this particular move and, in particular, whether this proposed move by the Queensland university is in the national interest. It has therefore been my view that the private inquiry that the committee has been undertaking should be a public inquiry, that it should report to this Senate and that we should encourage public debate on an issue which, on the face of it, will have very serious consequences within the higher education sector in this country.

In an effort to better inform the parliament and the public, I have moved this motion and trust that the Senate will give it support. It is set within a very tight time frame. The committee would have to report by 23 November, which would give us a week of sittings within which to debate any conclusions of the committee and thus reach a parliamentary position. That position should therefore be on the public record before the time for completion of the sale of the Bond University to the Queensland university. That information will no doubt also be helpful to the Queensland government—the Labor government that has just been re-elected—which also has to have a point of view. Senator Schacht, you might also tell us the attitude of your colleagues in Queensland, because the chances are that they will have to pass legislation within Queensland. You may have to pass legislation federally as a result of this purchase, and no doubt you were briefed on that as well.

So there are important issues. The debate should be on the public agenda and debated within the public. The parliament can help in that regard in this instance, and I therefore urge the Senate to adopt this reference and request the relevant committee to conduct the inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The University of Queensland was announced by KPMG as the preferred tenderer for the purchase of Bond University campus on Friday, 13 October 1995. The University of Queensland bid was accepted ahead of five other final tenderers. The reported sale price was $100 million. The purchase is subject to approval of the state government. It is also conditional on the University of Queensland being able to establish satisfactory access to finance and to gain control of Bond University Ltd, the company which operates Bond University. The University of Queensland has 60 days in which to finalise loan negotiations for the purchase and seek approval from the state Treasury.

It should be noted that the business Bond University is not part of the sale. The company Bond University Ltd, BUL, which is the operator of the business of the private university, has not been sold. The University of Queensland's bid is conditional upon gaining control of BUL, or Bond University Ltd.

It has been reported in the media that the Bond University council will fight the attempt to take control of BUL through the courts. If BUL decides to take this course of action, it is likely to lead to a protracted court battle, which could take months or even years to reach an outcome.

It is important to be clear that the University of Queensland intends to operate and expand the Bond campus solely as a private company. It will have completely separate management from the University of Queensland. In this respect, the University of Queensland is no different from any other purchaser.

The Commonwealth's position on the purchase of Bond University by a public university has been consistent and clearly articulated to all public universities that have expressed an interest in the purchase since the time that receivers were first appointed in August 1993. The Commonwealth has repeatedly stated that it would not oppose the purchase of Bond University by a public university, provided that there was no cross-subsidisation of private activities with public funds.

PARA.TAB: The government has therefore taken the view that it would be undesirable to intervene in what would be a commercial decision of a university. Furthermore, the act provides the Minister for Employment, Education and Training with no powers to prevent a public university from purchasing Bond University. Such a purchase would represent a commercial decision by a public university similar to the purchase of any other property or asset.

Institutions are prevented under the act from charging fees for undergraduate courses. However, an institution owning Bond University as a commercial venture would not be in breach of the act if Bond maintained a legally separate identity. The minister has made it quite clear on a number of occasions that the government would not provide any assistance for, or guarantee any loans associated with, the purchase. This position has been conveyed to interested public universities through ministerial correspondence and discussions between the Department of Employment, Education and Training and institutions at senior officer level. The Commonwealth has also made it clear that the acquisition of the Bond University operations should not lead to any diminution of the quality and range of public university higher education provision.

In the case of the University of Queensland, I am advised that as recently as last Friday at the annual educational profiles meeting the Vice-Chancellor gave a complete and unequivocal assurance that the purchase and operation of the Bond campus would not involve any use of public funds and that its operation would effectively be quarantined from that of the University of Queensland as a public university. Assurances were also given at that meeting that there would be no diminution of the range and quality of courses that would be offered to students attending the University of Queensland. The Commonwealth would monitor the situation through the annual educational profiles process.

In the event that the purchase by the University of Queensland finally proceeds, the Department of Employment, Education and Training will initiate detailed discussions with the university to ensure that an effective and demonstrable barrier is built between the public and private operation of the university. This is likely to involve the annual provision of separate and independently audited statements for both its public and private operations and a requirement that there be no use of Commonwealth operating grant, research or capital funds. Apart from these specific measures, which will be developed in conjunction with the University of Queensland, the department will continue to monitor the publicly funded activities of the universities through its normal processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard this as a very important reference for Senate inquiry. I declare two personal interests in this matter. What we have heard is an admission by the government that there have been ministerial correspondence and discussions at a senior bureaucratic level. There needs to be public consultation about what will be the best way to preserve the assets we already have in higher education in this country.

What are the repercussions for this private university and any other private university, and what are the repercussions for public universities, especially for students and staff in those universities, from any of the solutions that might come forward to the question that Senator Schacht has flagged on behalf of the minister?

With regard to the decision announced by the receivers on Friday to declare the University of Queensland as a possible purchaser of Bond University, subject to three conditions, we have heard from the minister just now that there is a fourth condition. The third condition is that there be successful negotiations with Bond University Ltd. I understand very well that Bond University Ltd has made resolute decisions that they will not see any diminution in the standards of the courses that are established, the undertakings they have given students to complete degrees and the undertakings given to staff; and the objectives, the vision, the whole raison d'etre of Bond University will not be compromised by the new ownership arrangements. Bond University Ltd clearly will take those concerns to the negotiations with the potential purchaser.

I wish to strengthen Bond University Ltd's arm in ensuring all those good objectives. The fourth condition that the minister has flagged just now is that the minister, in private correspondence and at a senior bureaucratic level—not public—has said that the arrangements for the new owner's relationship with Bond University Ltd must be such that there is not a use of public funds for private purposes. How could that ever be guaranteed? I put that to the Senate because whenever any public university borrows, let us say, $100 million to purchase a private university or any private activity, it gives some guarantee to the creditor—the bank or other agency from which it is borrowing the money—that in default of the loan there will be something that is claimable, to meet the advanced credit.

We know from all sorts of public institutions, including Aboriginal communities, that this is an enormously difficult matter to guarantee. One of the sadnesses we observe in the case of Aboriginal communities is that where land is vested in that community forever, it is not negotiable—a mortgage cannot be put on it. It is not subject to being advanced to fulfil any borrowings if they get into trouble. Therefore, a bank cannot give loans to many Aboriginal communities because they have not got a negotiable asset to forgo in the event of any difficulty arising in the project.

In the case of Queensland university, how can there be any guarantee of a loan, even if $100 million is borrowed to buy a private undertaking, unless there is a negotiable asset presently owned by the University of Queensland that would be forgone if there were any difficulty in purchasing that private university or any other private entity? The University of Queensland could have said that it would buy an industrial factory worth $50 million and work as the owner of that factory for the benefit of its engineering and research students. It would have an applied arm that would be directly owned by the university.

If it went into that sort of undertaking, it would not only need to meet its own tests for the viability of the project—that it was a profitable undertaking—but also satisfy itself as to how it would pay for the loan if anything went wrong with that commercial undertaking. I want to be satisfied about this. I believe that the staff associations of our universities need to be satisfied about it, as do the students.I am not shutting any door on a proposal that is in the national interest or that meets the scrutiny of all the questions that we are now raising in this debate.

Another major concern is our private universities. I want to make sure that we protect the integrity and the best interests of our private universities. Let us face it: the present government has done very little to assist either of the two private universities that currently exist. A couple of others are being planned. In the days of former Minister Dawkins, in particular, doors were shut and every barrier was put in the way. The existing private universities in Australia have managed to get over those barriers and prosper nevertheless.

The government's placing difficulties in the path of private universities has moderated in recent times. In the Senate, there has always been a lively debate that has included Senator Bell and his colleagues, Senator Tierney, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Employment and Training, you, Mr Acting Deputy President Senator Colston, as a former chairman of this committee and me as a former chairman of that committee. We will then hold not only this government in its last months but a future government—my colleagues will be in government very soon—to a well-formed set of guidelines for public policy with regard to public universities and private universities and the relationship between the two of them.

I do not shut the door to any outcome. I am not prejudiced as to the results of this inquiry. As a member of that Senate standing committee and a long-serving senator with an interest in higher education policy, I implore the Senate to unanimously support this reference. We should get on with it and make a contribution to policy debate in this matter.

While most of those statements are aimed at federal MPs generally, it is safe to assume that the 79 per cent who believe federal MPs can't be trusted to keep election promises are thinking exclusively about federal Labor MPs. After all, they have been the only group of federal MPs who have had the opportunity to break election promises over the past 13 years. And let's face it, they have turned the breaking of election promises into an art form.

For example, all Australians will recall the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to provide Australians with income tax cuts. What happened to that? It was broken without so much as a beg your pardon. Politicians cannot continue to treat voters with the contempt that Mr Paul Keating and the Labor government have shown over the past 13 years and expect to be held in high regard themselves. Voters are saying enough is enough, and that is reflected in the Morgan poll results. It is reflected in the results I have already outlined and is reflected in other results as well.

For example, more electors, that is, 39 per cent, believe that federal MPs attach greater importance to their own interests than to those of their electorate, 36 per cent, or of their party, 22 per cent. Not only that, but 52 per cent of voters believe that the quality of federal politicians is worse than it was 20 years ago. Coincidentally, that corresponds with the period Mr Keating has been a member of parliament.

More specifically, if we go back 20 years looking for a reason why community attitudes have declined, we can identify one possible cause: the appointment of Mr Keating as Minister for Northern Australia in 1975. It was only a short appointment because the government was swept from office later that year; but it must have had some impact on the public imagination, because public attitudes towards federal MPs have declined ever since that time. They have shown a greater rate of decline during the Hawke and Keating years than at any other time in recent history.

What is the solution? There are a number. Firstly, a change of government and a replacement with a government which is seen to be honest and caring. Clearly, a Howard coalition government can offer that hope. Secondly, the adoption of a code of conduct. As senators are aware, there is currently a draft before both houses of parliament. While I think we are probably heading in the right direction with it, I believe it is one area in which we should act sooner rather than later. With different state parliaments having adopted or being in the process of adopting codes of conduct, and with many of the professions having adopted codes, I do not believe that we can afford to be tardy.

Members of the public have traditionally expected MPs to adhere to higher than normal standards of probity. Unfortunately, recent events at a state and federal level have shown that some MPs are not maintaining the standards expected of us. I think it is fair to argue that the Easton affair and other similar inquiries are having a negative impact on public perceptions of members of parliament, both state and federal. My concern is that, while that continues to be the case, the public opinion polls will continue to rank us well down the ladder in terms of ethics and honesty and not up at the top where we should be, given public expectations of us.

This is highlighted by the results of another Morgan poll, which was conducted last April, which showed that community attitudes towards federal members of parliament had fallen dramatically during the Hawke and Keating years. In 1983, 19 per cent of Australians rated federal MPs very high or high in terms of ethics and honesty. That in itself is something to be concerned about, because it suggests that 81 per cent either believed federal MPs to be unethical and dishonest, or they didn't have a view. My feeling is that it would be the former rather than the latter. By April of this year that figure had fallen to 9 per cent.

The only good news in the poll was the fact that we still rate marginally better than newspaper journalists, at 8 per cent. The bad news is that we rank 22 out of 24 of the occupations included in the survey; the third worst, behind newspaper reporters and car salesmen.

It is time that members, individually and collectively, decided to do some image improving. I think a change of government and the prompt adoption of a code of conduct would go some way towards achieving that goal. They would certainly help to restore public faith in politicians and the political institutions we manage.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I want to deal with a most extraordinary statement by Senator Cook today. According to the latest budget, it has increased by 50 per cent.

Before the last election, sales tax collections for the year to 30 June 1992 were $9.3 billion and this year they are budgeted to be $14 billion—a 50 per cent increase. When you add them all together, Mr Keating's consumption taxes total about $30.7 billion in the current budget—almost $8 billion or one-third more than the dreaded consumption tax that Mr Keating opposed at the last election. Far more than Dr Hewson's consumption tax is Mr Keating's consumption tax—up 50 per cent.

Let us see what this means to the ordinary family. Let us compare this sneaky, hidden Keating sales tax with the more open, honest, evident one that Dr Hewson was recommending. The Keating government has raised the sales tax rates yet again in July of this year in a secret way so that the Keating sales tax now represents an average $60 a week for a four-person family. When Mr Keating became Treasurer 12 years ago, sales tax represented only $17 a week for a family. We keep on hearing all these comparisons with the bad old days when John Howard was Treasurer. This year, the Keating sales tax will rip $14,000 million from Australian consumers—that is four times as much as in Mr Howard's last year—hitting hardest, of course, the lowest income earners.

This Keating sales tax is a consumption tax, one of those consumption taxes that all of us should remember, because Paul Keating promised to oppose these in the 1993 election campaign. The Keating sales tax in the latest budget takes about $800 a year per head. It would have taken even more if the coalition had not blocked the Keating government's plan for a new $200 million tax on home building.

On top of that the petrol tax—another Keating consumption tax—has gone up 43 per cent to its highest ever level in Australia's history of $10,300 million, or almost $600 a year for every man, woman and child in Australia. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the loan and subsidy of some $7.59 million given as part of the Structural Adjustment Package to a company called Plywood and Plastics Pty Ltd and other associated companies and people as a result of World Heritage Listing of the wet tropics rainforest during 1988, 1989 and 1990:

(1) What investigations were carried out, authorised or instructed by the department in relation to: (a) recovery of monies in civil action: (b) legal action under the Trade Practices Act or other Commonwealth legislation: and (c) criminal or quasi-criminal action: and can copies of reports and advises in relation to these matters be provided.

(2)(a) What actual legal action was commenced: (b) what is the history of any such action: (c) please provide in detail: (i) terms of any settlements reached, (ii) particulars of judgements entered into, (iii) details of the dates and amounts of any monies recovered, (iv) details of any monies yet to be recovered, and (v) any continuing action: and (d) what are the details of any future action contemplated, intended, or to be investigated.

(3) In relation to the above matters please provide full and complete details of correspondence written and received and instructions given to and received from: (a) the Department of Finance: (b) the Director of Public Prosecutions: (c) the Australian Federal Police: and (d) the Department of Environment, Sport and Territories.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Attorney-General's Department is not an investigatory agency. In particular, the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS) acts upon instructions from client Departments and agencies.

The Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) also is not an investigatory agency. The DPP acts on prosecution briefs and other material received from the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Securities Commission and other agencies.
I am advised that the records of the Australian Federal Police do not indicate that any AFP investigation was carried out in relation to this matter.

I am advised that in August 1991 the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) commenced under section 13 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 a formal investigation of allegations raised in relation to the operation of Plywood and Plastics Pty Ltd and other associated companies. In relation to the loan and subsidy given under the Structural Adjustment Package, the ASC did not find any breaches of the Corporations Law in its preliminary investigation concerning the use of Commonwealth funds. The ASC investigated other matters unrelated to the loan and subsidy which involved breaches of the Corporations Law and provided a brief to the DPP. The ASC assisted the then Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) in relation to civil recovery proceedings by releasing information under section 127 of the Australian Securities Commission Act to the AGS. Reports and advice in relation to this investigation, which are subject to legal professional privilege, public interest immunity and obligations of confidentiality and secrecy under the Australian Securities Commission Act, cannot be made available to Senators.

(2)(a) The AGS, through its Sydney Office, was instructed by the then Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (DASET) to commence civil proceedings under the Trade Practices Act to recover monies from Plywood & Plastic Pty Ltd and other associated companies and people associated with those companies. Proceedings were commenced in the Federal Court of Australia on 3 July 1992. Those proceedings involved a Statement of Claim which pleaded a breach of section 52 of the Trade Practices Act.

(b) The decision to commence proceedings on 3 July 1992 was made in order to protect any claim the Commonwealth may have in relation to payments made by the Commonwealth on or after 4 July 1989 from becoming statute barred. On the advice of Senior Counsel, the Statement of Claim was not served upon any of the respondents named in it. The Court was informed of the Commonwealth's intentions.

Once the case preparation was completed and all evidence marshalled, the decision was made, again on Senior Counsel's advice, to discontinue those proceedings and commence new proceedings focusing on claims (which were not statute barred) against three of the original respondents to the Statement of Claim. Accordingly a second Statement of Claim, again pleading a breach of section 52 of the Trade Practices Act, was filed on 10 December 1992 and duly served upon the respondents. The three respondents to the second Statement of Claim were National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd (In Liquidation), Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd and Hugh Ferguson Macdonald.

As noted above, the Statement of Claim filed in the Federal Court of Australia on 3 July 1992 was filed in order to preserve the Commonwealth's position. The Statement of Claim filed on 10 December 1992 was a refinement of the earlier Statement of Claim which had regard to the evidence which had come to light.

The alleged misleading and deceptive conduct which was the subject of the Statement of Claim concerned events prior to the payment of a subsidy as part of a structural adjustment package under a program administered by DASETT which was designed to assist persons and businesses disadvantaged in Northern Queensland by the World Heritage Listing given to the Queensland rainforest.

"The Commonwealth entered into an agreement with Plywood & Plastic Pty Ltd ("Plywood"), the former owner of the Ravenshoe Sawmill in June 1988 to provide financial assistance to enable the restructuring of the sawmill following World Heritage Listing of the wet tropics of North Queensland. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 29 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to reports in July 1995 from New South Wales that body builders are injecting animal steroids in an attempt to build their muscles, and with reference also to the comments on 23 July 1995 of Dr Tony Sullivan, head of the Androgenic Anabolic Steroid Clinic at St Vincent's Hospital in Sydney, that up to half the steroids taken illegally by body builders were veterinary products meant for animals such as sheep and cattle:
(1) Does the Government know how widespread this problem is; if not, is it taking any steps to establish the extent of the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government is aware that veterinary steroids are used illegally by body builders. It is difficult to quantify the exact numbers of people abusing steroids and, in particular, those who are illegally using animal steroids as body building agents but the issue is being addressed as part of a comprehensive steroids strategy. A question on use of steroids was included for the first time in the 1995 National Drug Strategy Household Survey. The results of the survey indicated that less than 1% of the population had used steroids in the last 12 months. The survey did not attempt to distinguish the type of steroids used.

All anabolic substances, whether they be designated for animal or human use, entering Australia are subject to import controls. People wishing to import steroids must seek permission from my Department which takes steps to minimise the risk that those imports are diverted to the illegal market.

The National Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee (NDPSC) has recommended controls on the availability of anabolic steroids such that they be available only on prescription (Schedule 4), and the States should impose additional regulations which would make it illegal to possess these drugs without authority.

An exception has been made for testosterone esters which have a specific therapeutic use for the treatment of pizzle rot in sheep. These steroid hormones have both androgenic (masculinising) and weak anabolic properties and are listed as Schedule 6 poisons to facilitate their use by farmers.

Controlling the supply of steroids is a major focus of the National Anabolic Substances Strategy which was endorsed by the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy in June 1995. The Government is working with State and Territory governments, as well as non-Government groups including veterinary associations, to implement the National Strategy and reduce the harm to the Australian community caused by abuse of anabolic substances including steroids.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the maximum achievable rate of fire for: (a) the F88 Steyr assault rifle; and (b) the F89 Minimi submachine gun.
(2) What are the intended battlefield uses for each of the weapons.
(3) What instructions have been issued to Australian Defence Force personnel concerning the proper use and handling of the weapons.

(4) What instances have been reported of weapon malfunctions or failures, including details of: (a) date; (b) place; (c) purpose of weapon use; (d) cause of malfunction/failure; and (e) remedial action taken.

(5) With reference to an incident reported by the Director-General of Public Information, Brigadier D'Hage, in the Australian of 28 August 1995: (a) when and where did the incident occur; (b) why did the soldier concerned fire 700 rounds of ammunition; (c) what instructions was the soldier acting on, and given by whom; and (d) what action was taken in response to the incident.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) 850 rounds per minute.
(b) 1150 rounds per minute.

(2)(a) The intended use of the F88 Steyr Individual Weapon is to provide accurate semi-automatic fire out to a range of 300m and also to provide automatic fire for short durations at shorter ranges or in emergency situations.
(b) The intended use of the F89 Light Support Weapon is, through the provision of high volumes of accurate automatic fire, to gain immediate firepower ascendancy in the firefight.
(3) The current references for instructions are:

(a) For the Steyr, the Manual of Land Warfare Part 2, Volume 4, Pamphlet 9, Individual Weapon Steyr 5.56mm. ADF personnel are required to qualify after receiving instruction on the weapon to ensure safety standards are maintained.

(b) For the Minimi, the Manual of Land Warfare part 2, Volume 4, Pamphlet 10, Light Support Weapon, Minimi 5.56mm. ADF personnel are required to qualify after receiving instruction on the weapon to ensure safety standards are maintained.

(4) Details of reported failure for the Steyr and Minimi have been forwarded separately to the honourable senator. Details provided are date, reporting unit, and the failure/malfunction as reported by the unit. Data is not available for place of malfunction or failure and purpose of weapon use at the time. The data sheets contain comments on cause and remedial action.
(5)(a) The incident referred to in the Australian on 28 August 1995 occurred in Thailand on 25 July 1994.

(b) The soldier fired between 540 and 570 rounds over a period of 10 to 11 minutes as a member of a fire support group during a company level live firing attack. During the assault, it became obvious to safety officers that two sections of the platoon providing fire support needed to cease firing to ensure the safety of the assaulting troops. As a result of this, the third section of the fire support platoon increased its fire to compensate for the lack of fire from the other two sections.
(c) The soldier was acting on fire orders given by his section commander.

(d) The incident was formally investigated. The investigation found that the firer was acting on fire control orders of his section commander and no disciplinary action was taken against him. The use of the weapon on this occasion was not appropriate to its intended use. The deficiency has subsequently been addressed and information has been circulated to ensure that commanders and soldiers are aware of the limitations of firing the weapon on automatic for extended times.
